dublin_core.dcvalue: BACKGROUND Mobile phone technology is a novel way of delivering health care and improving health outcomes This trial investigates the use of motivational mobile phone text messages SMS to improve adherence to antiretroviral therapy ART over six months METHODOLOGY PRINCIPAL FINDINGS CAMPS was a single site randomized two arm parallel design trial in Yaound Cameroon We enrolled and randomized HIV positive adults on ART aged 21 years and above to receive a weekly standardized motivational text message versus usual care alone The primary outcome was adherence measured using a visual analogue scale VAS number of doses missed in the week preceding the interview and pharmacy refill data Outcomes were measured at 3 and 6 months Service providers and outcome assessors were blinded to allocation Analysis was by intention to treat Between November and December 2010 200 participants were randomized with 101 in the intervention group and 99 in the control group At 6 months overall retention was 81 5 We found no significant effect on adherence by VAS 95 risk ratio RR 1 06 95 confidence interval CI 0 89 1 29 p 0 542 reported missed doses RR 1 01 95 CI 0 87 1 16 p 0 999 or number of pharmacy refills mean difference MD 0 1 95 CI 0 23 0 43 p 0 617 One participant in the intervention arm reported a possible disclosure of status CONCLUSIONS SIGNIFICANCE Standardized motivational mobile phone text messages did not significantly improve adherence to ART in this study Other types of messaging or longer term studies are recommended REGISTRATION 1 Pan African Clinical Trials Registry PACTR201011000261458 2 Clinicaltrials gov NCT01247181
